reasoning: The critique targets a fairly central optimistic pathway in the essay: that partial AM-convergence plus bargaining/trade can yield mostly-great futures even without WAM-convergence. If AM agents systematically fail to become bargaining-relevant, that pathway weakens significantly, though the essay has other (weaker) sources of optimism and explicitly lists concentration-of-power / decision-procedure issues as blockers. Strength is therefore moderate-to-low: the countermodel is coherent and would block the trade mechanism, but it largely reiterates a risk the essay already acknowledges (section 3.5), so it doesn’t newly refute much unless the essay’s optimism depended more strongly on ignoring this blocker than it actually does. The critique is mostly correct conceptually (existence of AM agents ≠ leverage), though it somewhat overstates how “load-bearing” the 1-in-a-million premise is for the paper’s overall conclusion. It is clear, tightly focused on one issue, and contains little extraneous material.
title: Partial convergence fails without a model of how AM agents gain bargaining leverage
